name: Lifelong Learner
comment info:
A Messy-cum-Tricky Graph

At first glance, it seems to provide data regarding the amount of time spent readinng a privacy policy and the readibility of text. 
But if I dig deeper, it could not help us actually compare between any two companies' privacy policy. 
For example, if we take two companies on the graph having nearly same reading time ( Netflix and Reddit) and compare them, they have considerable difference in readibility, which suggests that Netlix's would be harder to read than Reddit. So, if reading Netflix's is hard, it should take more time to read than Reddit given the fact that both of them have same reading minutes.

name: Emily GIlmore
comment info:
Internet Privacy Policies; excruciatingly long by accident or by design? 

After reading this article, I noticed that the Airbnb privacy policy takes the longest amount of time to read compared to the others, while something like craigslist takes little to none.  It seems companies aren't trying to have their customers read what's laid out for them, hoping people will accept the agreement and turn a blind eye, which makes me wonder if the companies hire people to make these long and grueling terms of service lists on purpose.

This graph is aimed at making average people more aware of how ridiculous these terms and services are in both time and average readability, it shouldn't take a person as long as a movie to read and fully comprehend the terms and service of an app or website before you even use it.

name: Jude Lucido
comment info:
Headline: Scattered Information
I think this graph shows people's lack of care to read privacy policies. Not many people will sit through 10-20+ minutes of a college reading level policy, they just don’t see the point in that. Maybe companies make their policies challenging to read on purpose, to make people mindlessly agree to something. It’s a lot easier to get away with selling people’s information when they agree to let you do it.

name: Mariam
comment info: I notice some dots are light grey and some are black  and that most of the websites and apps privacy policies are over a high school level. This makes me wonder why they would do this, like for example Snapchat allows users 13+ to create an account but shouldn’t the policy be readable for a 13 year old if that is the age requirement to create an account on this app? It also makes sense why rarely anyone sits and reads these policies if they have to spend and average of 10 to 30+ minutes. Most teens I know wouldn’t spend even 5-10 minutes reading these policies just assuming it tell how their privacy is protected. Which they think they already know and, some just don’t care. I believe that companies do this because they spend so much time making these apps and websites and advertising them  but they don’t really know how to tell consumers through their advertisements that “hey this app is awesome but here, is the data we are collecting on you if you decide to use our app” without scaring away consumers. So they makes them shorter to read time wise but at a difficultly level which is not appropriate for the youth of this generation that use these apps around 12-13 years old and some even younger.

name: Ryan Johnson
comment info:
I noticed that the majority of the surveyed businesses have privacy policies with a readability score above 1300. A reading score of 1300 marks the beginning of the college level complexity range. 

I wonder why the majority of these corporations’ privacy policies are written in a more complex manner that’s more difficult to comprehend from the perspective of a consumer. As a high school consumer of these services, I feel that it is necessary to possess a genuine understanding of my data and how it’s used and distributed. However, due to my current educational background, this understanding I desire is likely much harder for me to grasp in comparison to a college student or professor capable of reading at this level. Ironically, only 33% of Americans over the age of 25 have a college degree that would enable them to do so. It is no secret that there are far less Americans who have graduated college than those who have. So then why would these corporations choose to make their privacy policies so strenuous?

Corporations take advantage of the uneducated public to hide their true intentions “stated” in their privacy policies.

name: Fariyal
comment info: I noticed that the graph depicts the level of difficulty in reading the privacy policies of websites. I’ve noticed that most big corporations use difficult language at a professional level in their policies. I’ve also noticed that most of these companies have policies that take 20-40 minutes to read.  This is because the high reading level makes it difficult for people to understand the policies, so it takes them longer to read. I wonder how they collected this information? Were people asked to read these policies for an experiment, and if so, how many people were taken into account ? I’ve also noticed that the books that were compared to these policies are usually books that are taught in high school. Most of these books are old, so the diction is very difficult, and most people struggle to comprehend these books . However, this graph shows that these texts were easier to read than most of the privacy policies for big companies. So, I think  this graph is attempting to convey the message that big corporations use difficult diction in their policies to scam people into quickly subscribing or using their website/app. Most people will tend to quickly skim over the policies, due to the difficult language, because it’s not likely they would spend 20-40 minutes reading and comprehending this information. These policies could contain loopholes or risks involved in that app that people won’t be able to recognize and may regret later when a problem occurs within the website/app.

I wondered why CNN and BBC and at different levels, BBC was lower than high school level reading while CNN was by the professional career reading level. They are both news websites that are similar but it’s interesting to see that they have different reading levels for their privacy policies. I noticed that Airbnb took the longest minutes to read which I can understand because there are so many policies but I wondered why it was at the professional career reading level. I also noticed that the text that was a lighter gray were all books. The deeper story of the graph shows that they are many different websites, apps, and books, with different levels of reading and larger company websites have more higher reading levels. It shows how companies write their privacy policies and how some are more difficult to read than others.

name: Jack
comment info: From noticing the graph, I feel that most major networks’ privacy policies fall at the minimum of a college level reading, making it difficult for those who may be bellow that certain reading level. Major networks like Snapchat, Netflix, and Facebook have a very wide range of audience, and its important for them as a customer of these companies’ services to understand what their private info is being used for. Companies could make these choices to distract people from seeing the real truth as to what they doing with their private info.

replies.name: R
replies.comment info: @Jack I agree with Jack that social media networks such as Snapchat, Netflix, and Facebook have a very wide range of audience which most likely effects the category they fall under in the scatterplot graph. I wonder if certain audiences based on gender and age have different impacts on the types of privacy policies used for each company.

name: Marena
comment info: This New York Times graph identifies how difficult it is to read an app’s or website’s privacy policies and how long it take to read. The graph is also split into sections showing which app/website policies are at a high school reading level, a college reading level, and a professional career reading level. What I wonder about this graph is: why there’s books included in the graph, what are the other black unlabeled dots, and how was the readability score measured for each of them? This graph can be used in many ways. For example, this can give teachers ideas to articles that their students can analyze in class depending on if they’re a high school or college student. This graph can also be used for new apps and websites to see how other apps/websites organize their privacy policies. Most of the privacy policy articles are towards the college reading level and above, making their policies harder to read and understand so that more people end up not reading it and accept anyway. Not knowing what they could have just gotten themselves into, which is what companies want.

name: Brianna
comment info: I noticed that the reading levels of apps’ and websites’ privacy policies shown in this graph tend to match the assumed reading level of the majority of their audiences. I wondered, how are companies developing their policies that way? I also noticed that there are 4 popular, and classic books at the 4 different reading levels to compare to the apps and websites. Why were these specific books chosen? Is it conveying that popular media is “dumbed” down for the general public? I also noticed that some of the biggest companies are located at the highest reading level. Why is this?

name: Brooke
comment info: The graph, at first glance shows the difficulty of reading certain companies privacy policies. As someone who is familiar with certain businesses presented on the graph, I have never read one privacy policy. As consumers, we want to continue on the app, skipping through the “boring” agreements when we first purchase the app. Companies known for presenting news stories are seen towards the middle with the privacy policy taking 15-20 minutes to read. I believe the time taken to read the policy serves importance as it shows what type of companies may take longer to read. Certain social media apps are in the high school and college average lexile reading range, these apps are appealing to consumers. They wouldn’t put their policies in a professional career reading level if teenagers would skim the policy in the first place. I am curious what the dots not emphasized represent, other businesses? I am also curious why a popular app such as airbnb which can be used by anyone would have a such high reading level. Some consumers of the app may have not received high education and wouldn’t know how to comprehend the privacy policy. Businesses should appeal to the consumer. One can infer that companies towards the bottom of the reading level may be used by everyday people, such as “Amazon” or “home depot”. In my opinion, the deeper meaning is companies should appeal to their consumers.

name: Gustavo
comment info: One thing I wonder about is how Baidu, the Chinese replacement of google, has the highest reading level score, since China is known to track their citizens and their search history. For this reason it makes sense that they would attempt to use complex language to try to bypass criticism on their privacy policy. Tricky wordplay and confusing language can allow Baidu lawyers to get around lawsuits regarding someone’s information.

replies.name: C
replies.comment info: @Gustavo I find this to be really interesting. I had no idea Baidu was, but now that you mention its purpose I can totally see your reasoning. I wonder if this is the same reason that the BBC has such a low lexile score, being a news media organization created with the express purpose of bringing about transparency. I think it is interesting comparing the reading level and transparency of the Chinese vs. British organizations.

name: Mikaely
comment info: I wonder what is hidden in these privacy policies because I believe  that they wouldn’t be as long as they are if the companies aren’t trying to get our information. If companies are able to find out information about their users, what are they using it for? Walt Disney is a source of media for children with a streaming app and theme parks, so what are they doing with personal information and why is their privacy policy so long? It seems unnecessary, and a little suspicious to me.

replies.name: S
replies.comment info: @Mikaely I agree that companies are hiding things in their privacy policies by using more complex language to confuse people and get them to agree to their terms without fully reading/ comprehending the policy.

replies.name: R
replies.comment info: @Mikaely I somewhat agree with your opinion but a lot of the privacy policies have to do with the companies making sure they are legally ok, comanies like disney use you personal information to find out thing such as your date of birth to make sure they are showing appropriate things by age group. I do agree the length and reading levels of some of them seem a little suspiscious for the amount of information they should need.

name: Richie

I also noticed  that the books used in the scatterplot graph are scattered out randomly throughout the graph. name: Mahdi
comment info: I noticed that an app like Snapchat which many children that aren’t in high school use either requires almost college level reading.  I wonder why do they make it difficult for children who aren’t at that reading level yet. Especially an app like Snapchat were many controversies happen with under age kids.

replies.name: C
replies.comment info: @Mahdi I agree, it appears that companies are purposefully  trying to outsmart and manipulate their consumers base into unwittingly giving up the majority of their privacy and their data rights.

replies.name: R
replies.comment info:
@Mahdi 
I agree with what you are saying here, I think that it is weird that companies that attract the youth have such a high reading level. I think the reason for this is valid though. I think that companies that deal with the youth especially, have to have a strong privacy policy and even though it creates a lot of reading at a high level, I believe it is for the best.

replies.name: A
replies.comment info: @Mahdi This is also something that stood out to me. Not only is important to consider how prevalent under-aged child controversies are, but it is also important to consider how much Snapchat allows us to store personal conversations and images. Since the privacy policies are so complex to read and are often ignored by users, Snapchat is making it possible for these users' information to be exposed, some of that information being extremely inappropriate and personal. Although it is not a good thing, nude pictures are commonly exchanged on Snapchat. If these images were to be shared, legal issues such as child pornography could occur.

name: Sophia
comment info: In the NYT graph I noticed different websites and apps that were being rated by there challenging text and how long it takes to read the privacy policies. It ranged from books, to social media sites, to news websites. The reading level of the privacy policies vary and so does the time of reading them. The wonders of the graph are how it’s arranged. Why is it that Walt Disney is so much harder to read then Snapchat privacy policies? Isn’t Walt Disney for children and Snapchat for teenagers? It should be very close in range of reading levels. The reasons Walt Disney is a harder reading level is because it has more regulation and information that needs to be read for its website. It’s such a big network and has more complex terms then Snapchat would. That’s why it’s categorized into the Professional Career section rather then high schools reading level, like Snapchat is. This graph is trying to show that even though some of these apps, networks, websites, or books are for certain ages to use, its privacy policies are based on its popularity and how the company wants to protect themselves with there rulings.

name: Olivia
comment info: This graph is set up in a way that compares website and app privacy policies’ difficulty and how long they take to read. The first thing I noticed was that many social media pages share similar reading levels, though some take longer to read than others. The next thing I noticed was that larger companies or news sites typically had a much higher readability score than the rest of the graph, yet remained in a medium area for how much time it took to read. There are also popular novels in more faded texts, likely placed to help guide a viewers understanding of the difficulty of each policy. I do wonder what the other smaller dots are meant to represent, although I am guessing that they are smaller name companies or apps. I believe that the deeper story within this graph is to show how the larger companies typically use more confusing or higher level writing, which may confuse or put off the reader from completely analyzing the policies, as shown in larger companies like GoDaddy, Walt Disney, CNN, and CNS Sports. Their reading levels are higher yet time taken to read is low, likely due to readers skimming long privacy policies instead of taking the time to struggle through the more difficult writing. Whether intentional or not, these companies show an odd ratio between difficulty and time taken to read, while social media companies like Snapchat and Reddit maintain a medium difficulty with a medium time taken to read.

name: Max R
comment info: I noticed a majority of the higher difficulty sources are news related or are directed towards a older audience which validates the increase in difficulty as the audience has a more mature and educated reading ability. But those sources are all in a window of time I takes to read, majority of them are in the 10-25 minute range, few take longer than 25 or shorter than 10. So the attention span of the reader dictates the length of the article. I wonder why social media platforms such as Snapchat, reddit, and Facebook focus on a high school and above audience, when most kids are downloading such apps at a youthful age. Why not gear the apps to best fit the audience? Social media is used by the youth, no as much by the middle age and the elederly. And the youth have a high school if not lower reading ability. I can infer that there exists a sweet spot from the sources difficult to the sources length. That sweet spot appears to be at a collegiate reading level with a source that ranges from about 10-20 minutes in reading length. the sources are intentionally doing that to maintain a professional read that is still readable in short period of time. This difference shouldn’t discriminate those without the abilities. The opportunities to read and enjoy those sources should be available to all reading abilities and not just the select few. So I belive the point of the graph was to show lack of unity in sources, and how there is a lack of sources that everyone can enjoy.

replies.name: J
replies.comment info: @Max R I agree to question you brought up in regarding to these companies making their apps better suitable to their consumer. I feel that companies are becoming more and more protective of their power rather than complying with the audience who use their products. Today we are becoming more and more digital as a society and its important for these major companies to take in to consideration the massive amounts of data they collect on a day to day basis.

name: gwyn
comment info: In this NYT graph one could wonder if the distinguish between high school, college, and professional reading level all simulate to a common conclusion that as one gets older do they read more about new upbringings to todays world. For example, the graph shows that professional levels read about Walt Disney along with CBS Sports, therefore one can infer that it seems professionals want to learn more about the interests of common young adults in school who maybe enjoy sports. Digging on a deeper level could younger teens in high school want to read certain books that were created  in a earlier time? A thought for this would be that maybe teens in high school read Harry Potter  not only to just read the books but to connect to the professional level adults who grew up on the series themselves reading these books while in high school. Another example is BBC a news site that many adults tune in, which seems interesting that teens are taking interest in the site. One could believe that professional adults are trying to learn more about teens today to understand and connect but as on the contrary teens today try reading certain sources to connect to adults today and understand what professional adults grew up on.

name: Katherine
comment info: I noticed that the graph is using the first chapter of books to compare to popular websites and app privacy policies. I thought it was interesting that Craigslist’s policy and Pride and Prejudice were similar in both their readability score and minutes to read. Many of the apps or sites with significant purchases involved had privacy policies that took longer to read. I saw that major channels like CBS Sports and CNN scored very high in readability, but BBC ranked so low in comparison, yet it was about as long in time to read. I also noticed that the top readability score is not one commonly used by Americans.  website. I wonder who or what they used to test how long it took to read each chapter and policy. I thought it was interesting that the graph did not include anything other than BBC to be less than a high  school reading level and most every privacy policy is above that. I think it’s funny that all of these privacy policies are so complex and time consuming even though it is well known that most people skim over the policies.  I think it’s perfect that snapchats policy is about high school reading level since that is the consumer age they cater toward and most of their users.

name: Jessica
comment info: I noticed that a majority of these companies/businesses require a higher reading level than high school in order to be able to fully comprehend the details of their privacy policy. Many of these companies even require a college level reading skill, which many around the world do not have. This may be to keep the policy somewhat obscure. Are these companies attempting to shelter the content of their policies in order to publish information without the customer realizing? This would especially make sense for the companies that are involved with social media (snapchat, facebook, reddit, etc) due to the fact that their audience is mainly teenagers. More often than not, a high school teenager does not possess a reading level great enough to be able to read above a college level, let alone at professional level. This brings me to wonder, if anything, what are these companies hiding? And why are the novels that are being compared only judged to an extent of the first chapter?

name: Grace
comment info: I notice this graph takes into account the reading difficulty of a company’s privacy policy as well as how long it might take someone to actually read it. The graph also has fainter points representing popular books which I assume is to give people observing this graph an idea of what the “reading levels” actually are. I’m curious what the unlabeled points represent most other points show what company is being analyzed. I’m also curious as to why Walt Disney has such a difficult reading policy. More social networking and entertainment companies seem to have policies that are fairly easy reads, while news companies or companies that provide a service have longer or more complex privacy policies. I’m assuming the discrepancies between a few similar companies reading level and length deal with viewer demographics. BBC’s target audience is adults around the age of 35, while 39% of CNN’s audience is over 65. BBC has a policy reads around the same difficulty as Harry Potter and The Sorcerer’s Stone while CNN reads around 1600 difficulty. Obviously tech companies like Baidu and GoDaddy have intense policies because they are big companies. This graph seems to show how hard various companies work protect themselves.

name: Jensen
comment info: A common similarity between this graph is that most website and app privacy policies take about 10-20 minutes to read despite the difficulty of the reading level. I believe that the time taken to read has less so do with the reading level because people can understand the gist of the privacy policy without needing over 20 minutes to read it. The time is more related to a persons curiosity of the rules  and rights, another possible factor is when money is involved the person is more likely to want to know what they are getting into beforehand. For example an Airbnb takes the most time to read because you are investing your own money into it, and a person is probably more curious about the rules of an Airbnb because it is another persons property.

replies.name: E
replies.comment info: @Jensen That's a very interesting way to interpret the graph! Your logic is very sound and makes a lot of sense. I also think that some companies make their privacy policy harder to read because they are appealing to their audience or trying to hide fraud behind it.

name: Ethan

name: John

name: Erin

replies.name: W

replies.name: M

name: Steven Lietz
comment info: In this graph I notice the topic, which is readability score vs. time to read. This graph is showing us based on reading ability, how long it may take to read an article from each of the different companies. I notice that companies that may have some youth included in the audience reading the article, may have a lower reading score or take longer to read. While companies that generally have an older audience may have higher reading score. Companies like snapchat, vimeo and craigslist allow most people of any age to be able to read and comprehend their articles well.  While companies like CNN, Indeed, and N.Y.T may have an older or more experienced reading audience. I also notice the book Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone to have a lower reading level as many children read it, while Critique of Pure Reason, is a book generally for an old audience. I think companies got their evidence from use of “cookies” to see what ages were on their website, and/or reading what article, and how long they were on it. This graph shows what age groups and reading levels people are at, possibly used for marketing techniques.

name: Aliah
comment info:

Apps and websites make complicated to read so no one is interested in them and skips over them.

name: Anjolie
comment info:
I first noticed the dots described at Snapchat, Walt Disney, and Netflix. These specific dots stood out to be because I am most familiar with them. name: Ameena
comment info: I noticed that the graph shows most privacy policies to be written at a college reading level and it makes me wonder how many people take the time to entirely read something that is perhaps formatted to include words that may not be understood by the customers but were rather put in for legal reasons. At the bottom of the graph, it shows that the reading time is based solely upon the first chapter and since a decent amount of popular sites are at the professional level, it makes me wonder how thorough customers are being with reading the content. Many customers, despite the reading levels, have been seen to have taken 10-20 minutes to get through the policies but how many pages does each chapter have. The graph also does not seem to include the amount of participants included to gather the data which also does make me wonder at how deeply this topic was investigated.

name: Gillian
comment info: From this graph, I notice that the majority of the points are in the college reading level category, mostly condensed between 10-20 minutes to read. The labeled companies on the graph are all big name companies, the companies that the majority of people would recognize. Websites or apps to sell things, like Etsy and Airbnb, have privacy policies that take longer to read. I wonder how the readability score was computed? Why do some dots have no label at all? How did they figure out what the reading level was, like high school, college, or higher? Why are all the popular apps or websites for my generation almost identical in their levels and time to read, such as Snapchat, Netflix, and Reddit? I can infer from this graph that companies strive for their policies to be a little difficult to understand for non-college level readers. Companies also seem to strive for their privacy policies to take a while to read, mostly longer than ten minutes, which in today’s society is a very long time. Most people just say that they read the policy without even reading it because of the complicated level and time it would take to actually read the policy. The deeper story seems to be that the more popular a company is in today’s society with my generation, the lower the reading level and the less time it takes to read. The companies have complicated privacy policies that may be confusing for their consumers to protect themselves from any retaliation.

replies.name: G

name: Katelyn M.
comment info:
1) The graph itself is a visual depiction of an ethical dilemma that puts every user of these websites at risk. On the surface, the graph depicts this notion that privacy policies are often above some users' comprehensible level; however, hidden within this idea is the fact that when users don't understand the conditions, they also cannot defend themselves from them either. 

2) The practice of creating predatory policies that can often circumvent legal protections is not a new concept; however, with more recent privacy crackdowns (such as policy coming from the EU), companies must find ways to maintain their questionable practices while also maintaining an illusion of transparency. YouTube recently came under legal scrutiny for their violations of privacy laws including children. Despite legal protections of children's data, they marketed themselves to advertising companies as a hub for kid-friendly content thus ensuring financial gain. Their defense was centered around their terms of service requiring users to be 13 years or older, yet they don't actually require verification. While they may have been penalized, many instances of predatory data collection fly under the radar.

3) With the rapid development of new technology and data that is readily accessible online, legal diction and confusing verbiage allows companies to take advantage of its consumers from monetary and legal gain. The only way to combat this is to move in the direction of the EU and modernize policy.

replies.name: B

Interesting points! I agree with point #3. I think it is interesting that many companies/well-known brands have privacy policies that are college-level when their product is directed for younger people. For example, Walt Disney, Netflix, and Snapchat are all widely used and known products/businesses for young adults and children, and yet one would most likely have to be in college to understand the policies.

name: Ian Condon
comment info:
In this graph, you notice how each reading level reflects the type of media of the website. For example, if you look at the professional career reading level, there are professional websites such as Salesforce, Indeed, and GoDaddy. All websites used by professionals. In the high school reading level, you see Snapchat and Reddit being present. The demographic that uses these websites has to do with the reading level. A website will get more clicks if it is able to be read by all demographics. For example, if you wanted your website to be read by high-schoolers and college students, you would make the reading level readable by the high schooler, because a college student can still read on a high school reading level, but the average high schooler can’t read on a college reading level.

Shorter reading times a lower reading level will capture the attention of the most people.

replies.name: M
replies.comment info: @Ian Condon  I really like the point you made about a website receiving more clicks if it was designed to be read by all demographics. I would like to add that the readability score of a website or company correlates to its intended and targeted audience.

replies.name: L
replies.comment info: @Ian Condon I totally agree with you. I feel that companies must include their private policies by law, but they also must inquire their audience. High school students (if they choose to) won't read an intense college written policy with sophisticated words. The more user-friendly applications are most likely the ones with less reading time and a low readability score.

replies.name: M
replies.comment info: @Ian Condon  I really like your point about a website receiving more clicks if the privacy policy was written in a way that was understood by all demographics. I would like to add that companies' privacy policies are usually written to be understood by their targeted audience but would receive more interaction if a wider audience understood the policies. It's like you stated before but in a different interpretation, a 2nd grader does not understand what a 5th grader is learning, but a 5th grader understands what a 2nd grader is learning, so policies should be written in a way that is understood by the vast majority.
